Great work with the submission!
Please find the annotated file, there are a few suggestion to improve your submission even further.

rubric.description:
Related Course: Content Strategy and Social Media Marketing Submission Type: PDF Review Time Estimate: 20 minutes Description: In this project we want you to practice producing and marketing content about a subject you know very well – yourself! First, you are going to write a blog post (minimum of 250 words and maximum of 500). Next, you’ll craft social media post for three social platforms to share your blog post with your audience. [DMND Reviewers Handbook](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gILVtaotovaqd1hc8b7fBwnBQNdKJlbq-agyvbOicI8/edit?usp=sharing) ---- **Make a copy of this [Google doc template](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1zm1S95IiUQ2cYddwUpsypEGQxrtwC_OF7M4fB3Ouw1s/edit?usp=sharing)** or download the PPT template from the resource section of this project. Make sure to complete each section. When you are ready, save your file as a PDF and submit it.
## Part 1: Getting Started *Below is an outline of what is required for this project. Please provide your answers in the project template.* Before you start crafting your blog post, you’ll want to think about the target persona that the post will be written for, the marketing objective for your blog post, and the KPI. 1. Provide the marketing objective for your blog post 2. Provide a KPI for your blog post 3. Copy and paste your Target Person from Project One and make any updates or changes based on your learnings from the previous project. ## Part 2: Write a Blog Post 1. Select a theme for your blog post: * Why have you decided to take the Digital Marketing Nanodegree Program? * Choose a successful or creative marketing campaign that you love. What is the story being told by the campaign and why do you love it, why did it catch your attention? 2. Select the framework you’ll be using to craft the content for your blog post: * SCQA, also called the Pyramid Principle *or* * Pixar framework 3. Write a blog post, with the theme you’ve chosen from the options above, in the space provided below. * Remember to keep in mind your target audience when crafting your post. Consider: What voice and tone are appropriate? * If you include media in your post, include it and make sure you are compliant with copyright laws. * Your post should be a *minimum of 250 words and maximum of 500.* ## Part 2: Craft Social Media Posts 1. List three social media platforms your target audience is likely to visit. Include, a short one or two sentences description of why you chose these channels. 2. Craft a post for each of the platforms promoting your blog. ** Optional Extra Credit:** While you don’t actually have to share your posts online to pass this project (you will submit it in a template), you are more then welcome to do so. Publish your posts on the platforms you have chosen and submit screenshots for review in the submission template. Where applicable include the hashtag #IminDMND, we'll select the best posts and share them on our social channels and share your results. ------- ### Rubric You can reference this project's [rubric](https://review.udacity.com/#!/projects/264/view) to review what your submission should include. ------- # Concepts: ## Storytelling Frameworks There are a number of different story structures you can use to build a personal connection and drive action. Here are two you should consider. SCQA, also called the Pyramid Principle and the Pixar framework **SCQA**: One framework you can use to create an engaging story is called SCQA which stands for situation, complication, question, and answer. The situation is a clear, crisp statement of the facts. It's the state of affairs as they are right now. Complication is the thing that's changed that makes things harder; the change in circumstances that you should be concerned about. Question normally falls out of the situation and complication. Like, what should we do? And Answer is the answer to this question - it usually resolves the complication. **SCQA Example:** Here’s how SCQA would apply to the story of Little Red Riding Hood. Situation: Little red riding hood walks through the woods to deliver food to her grandmother Complication: A wolf pretends to be her grandmother so that he can eat Little Red Riding Hood Question: How will she escape? Answer: A lumberjack comes to the rescue **Pixar**: The Pixar framework is from Pixar, a famous storytelling company responsible for some of the most popular animated movies of all time like Toy Story. Pixar’s stories follow this simple outline. Once there was a - usually a protagonist with a goal Everyday - describes the protagonist’s routine Until one day - something pivotal that changes everything Because of that- what follows as a result Because of that Until then - the protagonist reaches goal, but often not in the way they originally thought they would Ever since then - how the character and their situation has changed. **Pixar Example** Here’s how the Pixar framework would apply to Star Wars. Once there was a farm boy who wanted to be a fighter pilot Everyday he helped out on the farm Until one day his family is killed Because of that he joins Obi-wan kenobi Because of that there were lots of wars in stars. Until finally he becomes a star fighter pilot and saves the day Ever since then he’s known not only as a pilot but also a Jedi **Social Media Landscape and categories:** Much of the social media landscape falls into 6 main categories: Publishing, Sharing, Messaging, Discussing, Collaborating, and Networking. These categories describe how the respective social media channels are primarily used. It’s important to keep that in mind as well when you choose your channel and create content to fit that channel. What about the most popular social media sites? Many of these channels serve multiple purposes. For example, Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn allow for Publishing, Sharing, Messaging, Discussing, Collaborating, AND Networking. Whereas Pinterest and Instagram are more visual. But as they are mainly about photos, they are more static. YouTube is also visual but video is more dynamic. Snapchat takes visuals and the dynamics of video further by incorporating messaging.
